head.supplied: ¶ Submitted to the Council of the Acclimation Society. ¶ Ferd Mueller. ¶ 16/4/62....

div.p: V62/2549, unit 770, VPRS 1189/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof.
On 24 March 1862 G. Francis, Director of the Adelaide Botanic Garden, wrote to the Chief Secretary of Adelaide: 'The public prints disclose the fact that at the Botanic Garden Melbourne, a large number of certain animals exist, as Alpacas Fallow Deer, Curassows, Indian Doves, Singing birds and others. I have the honor to request in the name of the Board of Governors of our Botanic Garden that His Excellency the Governor in Chief will be pleased to suggest to the Government of Victoria that any animals or birds which can be spared would be very valuable in aid of the much smaller collection at our establishment. That the authorities at Melbourne may be enabled the better to assist us, I annex a list of all the animals we have, and merely add that all others will be very acceptable. We are ready to pay all attendant expenses, and will return such acceptable animals as we can spare from time to time; even now I am about to send some — and expect shortly to obtain others, already promised, (if procurable) — to Dr Müeller, who equally with myself has always been anxious to effect mutual exchanges to the benefit of both establishments. Animals and birds at the Botanic Garden Adelaide March 24.1862.
3 Common and 1 Red Kangaroo (male) | 6 Kangaroo Island Wallabies | 8 Kangaroo Rates ([...] campestris) | 4 Guinea Pigs | 2 Ring tailed opossums | 6 White opossum (Common ones not kept)
3 Native cats, 1 Monkey, 1 Angora Goat}
3 [...] Mongoose
} no others wanted
1 pair South Australian Wombats. }
2 Emus | 9 Black Swans | 2 White Swans | 6 Mountain Ducks. | 1 Fejee Duck | 1 Wood Duck | 1 Wood Duck | 3 Teal Duck | 3 Gulls (genus prion) | 1 Red Cory (Solomon Isles) | 1 Green King Parrot | 1 Pair small white Cockatoo | 1 Pair small pink Cockatoo | 6 Cockatoo parrots (1 Male 5 females) | 10 Shell Parrots | 2 Large white Cockatoos | 8 Cereopsis Goose | 2 Chinese Geese | 1 Blue Crane | 2 Stone Plovers called Curlews | 1 Tryloniae (water hen) | 1 Peaceful Dove | 4 Turtle Doves | 1 Wonga Pigeon | 5 Pea Fowl | 1 Pair Silver Pheasants | 1 Gold Pheasant (male) | 1 Pair English Pheasants | 5 laughing Jacasses | 1 Eagle Hawk (no other wanted) | 1 Owl (boobook) |2 kinds of Hawk | 3 Magpies (Colonial) | 1 Pair Nicobar pigeons | 2 Pair fancy pigeons | 1 Pair Adelaide parrots.'
On 9 April 1862 the Chief Secretary's Office at Adelaide sent the Chief Secretary of Melbourne, J. O'Shanassy: 'a copy of a communication addressed to me by the Governors of the Botanic Garden of Adelaide desiring me to suggest to the Government of Victoria that any animals or birds which can be spared from the Melbourne Botanic Garden, would be gladly received as a valuable addition to the much smaller collection at their institution. I shall be glad to hear that Dr Müeller will be able to comply with the Board's request, in which case I beg to suggest that the Directors of the respective Gardens should communicate with each other, and effect such exchanges as may mutually benefit both establishments.' The letter was referred to M.
See also M to J. O'Shanassy, 17 April 1862 and 24 April 1862.
Submitted to the Council of the Acclimation Society.
